Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: 2G for UG: High Data-rate and Long Range Communication Techniques for Wireless Underground Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to increase the communication ranges and data rates of buried radios by leveraging expertise in the nexus of computer science and engineering and biological systems engineering. The goals of this project are to characterize the underground channel; develop environment-adaptive solutions to achieve high data rate, long-range communications; and illustrate applications to agriculture and transportation. The emerging use of wireless underground sensor networks (WUSNs) in many areas, including precision agriculture, transportation, environment and infrastructure monitoring, and border patrol, underscores the importance of wireless underground (UG) communications. Yet, existing limitations in terms of communication ranges and data rates prohibit widespread adoption. The novel approaches developed in the project broaden the scope of existing and novel applications, leading to economically viable solutions. The results and the insight from this project have the potential to enable a wide array of novel solutions from saving water resources for more food production to saving lives on the roadways.

Extending the communication ranges and increasing data rates in wireless UG communications faces unique challenges because of the interactions between soil and communication components: (1) Antenna properties depend on soil type and vary with changes in soil parameters such as temperature and moisture. (2) Channel characteristics, such as delay spread and coherence bandwidth, are time-variant functions of the soil parameters. (3) The soil-air interface results in fluctuations in both antenna performance and EM wave propagation, which should be considered in system design. To address these challenges, the project captures the impulse response of the wireless UG channel through extensive experiments throughout the state of Nebraska, which is one of the most diverse states in terms of soil textural properties, climatic gradients, and land use. Based on this analysis, advanced modulation schemes are developed. Moreover, based on UG antenna analysis, long-range communication techniques are developed. Two distinct applications from agriculture and transportation are considered to evaluate the developed solutions in a crop field and a crash test site.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project are to characterize the wireless underground communication channels, develop environment-aware, cross-layer communication solutions to achieve high data-rate, long-range communications, and demonstrate the impact of underground communications in agriculture and transportation applications. The project also aims to capture and analyze the impulse response of the wireless UG channels.

Based on empirical evaluations and a statistical analysis, a statistical channel model for the UG channel is developed. The parameters for the statistical tapped-delay-line model are extracted from the measured power delay profiles (PDP). The PDP of the UG channel are represented by the exponential decay of the lateral, direct, and reflected waves. The statistical model can generate the channel impulse response to precisely predict the UG channel RMS delay spread, coherence bandwidth, and propagation loss characteristics in different conditions.  

A theoretical model is developed to use soil moisture information to improve wireless underground communication ranges. An array element in soil is analyzed empirically and impacts of soil type and soil moisture on return loss (RL) and resonant frequency are investigated. Accordingly, beam patterns are analyzed to communicate with underground and above ground devices. Depending on the incident angle, effects of the refraction from soil-air interface are ascertained. Beam steering to improve UG communications are developed by providing a high-gain lateral wave which leads to higher directivity in the wireless underground communications. It is shown that a beamforming mechanism that captures the soil type, soil moisture, and deployment depth can improve directivity and communication ranges compared to a beamforming solution that is tailored for over-the-air use. Moreover, soil moisture adaptive beamforming is shown to provide significantly higher directivity and hence, communication ranges compared to a static approach.

A soil monitoring method, Di-Sense, has been developed for real-time in situ estimation of relative permittivity of soil, and soil moisture, that is determined from the propagation path loss, and velocity of wave propagation of an underground (UG) transmitter and receiver link in wireless underground communications (WUC). The permittivity and soil moisture estimation processes are modeled and validated through an outdoor UG SDR testbed, and indoor greenhouse testbed. 

By using Di-Sense approach, soil moisture and permittivity can be measured with high accuracy in 1m to 15m distance range in plant root zone up to depth of 40 cm. The range of R2 value for different soils is 0.9212 to 0.9901. Di-Sense VWC model when compared with ground truth VWC measurements has high R2 values (greater than 0.9212) which shows a good agreement between ground truth measurements and the model. 

We conducted measurements using our testbeds to facilitate investigation on the inhomogeneities in wireless UG channels. The antenna return loss and channel power delay profile are measured for dipole and wideband micropatch antennas using our new testbed design.

The objectives of a part of this project were to: (a) evaluate nine commercial EM sensors for their overall performance to measure true θv under (i) silt loam, and (ii) loamy sand soils when installed in vertical and horizontal orientations; (b) develop calibration functions from data collected during an entire growing season for future use in the two soil types; (c) evaluate the calibrated θv for an independent growing season-wide dataset, based on improvement in accuracy achieved post-calibration; and (d) investigate and quantify the role/influence of season-wide temperature fluctuations on sensor performance.

During this project, the PI has organized four yearly vertical track events on Agricultural IoT in the IEEE World Forum on Internet of Things (WF-IoT) to bring in experts on agricultural IoT from both academia and industry together. 

We actively participated in the organization of local outreach events to share our research and education experience with students and teachers. We presented our research activities at Science Connectors showcases with Lincoln Public Schools (LPS) in 2018 and 2019 through easy-to-understand demonstrations (see http://cpn.unl.edu/projects/2G4UG). The main goal of these events is to inform the public-school teachers about state-of-the-art scientific research at the University of Nebraska and enable teachers to engage in building creative K-12 curricula. Co-coordinated by the LPS science curriculum specialist, this annual event shares STEM activities with over 150 science teachers at UNL. The LPS Science Connector events allowed teachers to learn about our experiences with embedded systems, wireless communications, and soil physics. Our interdisciplinary research inspires science teachers with their curriculum design and potentially enrich the learning experience for students.

This project supported three PhD and one MS students in computer science and engineering, and one MS students in biological systems engineering fields. One PhD student has joined Purdue University as an Assistant Professor and one female MS student has successfully completed her MS degree. 

The wireless underground communication techniques developed in the project have significant potential to improve precision agriculture techniques with low-cost solutions. Accordingly, significant savings can be achieved to help preserve precious water resources in the World.
